title: 5 things we learned from Pep Guardiola ahead of Man City's Champions League last-16 clash with Monaco

Manchester City will be looking to progress to the quarter-finals of the Champions League with victory over Monaco at the Stade Louis II on Wednesday night. 
In the first leg of the last-16 tie the Citizens stormed to a 5-3 win in what was one of the most exciting games in the competition's history. 
Raheem Sterling made it 1-0 at the Etihad Stadium before former Man United forward Radamel Falcao and Kylian Mbappe put the away side ahead. 
The Colombian then saw a penalty saved before Sergio Aguero equalised for Pep Guardiola's men 13 minutes after the break. Pep Guardiola speaks to the press ahead of the Monaco game (Photo: REUTERS) 
But the goals didn't stop there. Falcao made it 3-2 to the away side, which kicked City into life and saw them score another three before full time. 
Aguero grabbed the second equaliser before John Stones put the Citizens in front. Leroy Sane extended the advantage ahead of the second leg with a goal in 82 minutes. 
Guardiola spoke to the press ahead of Wednesday's return fixture, discussing team news, his aspirations in the competition and his own future. Here are five things we learned. There will be no Barcelona return for Pep 
The Man City boss had been tipped as one of the potential successors to Luis Enrique at the end of the season. 
Guardiola managed the Catalan giants between 2008 and 2012 - one of the most successful periods in the club's history. Guardiola is not interested in taking over from Luis Enrique at Barcelona (Photo: Getty Images) 
But he told reporters that he will not be returning to the Nou Camp and remains fully focused on taking City forward. 
"Never again," Guardiola said when asked about a potential return. "My period at Barcelona is over." The Monaco game will be an open encounter 
Manchester City might be going into the game with a two-goal lead, but they are also going into it having conceded three away goals. 
Speaking ahead of the clash, Guardiola acknowledged the fact that Monaco want to be in the quarter-finals as much as them. Guardiola expects there to be more goals on Wednesday night (Photo: Reuters) 
This means that if Man City are to progress in the competition they are going to have to play positively and ensure they don't rest on their laurels. 
"I want to see my team with the feeling to win the game. I encourage them to play their game and to score goals," said the Spaniard. European success remains a mystery - but City will try 
Guardiola admitted he has no idea whether his team have the capabilities to win the Champions League this season. 
But he insisted that they will try their hardest to make the dream a possibly. 
Speaking ahead of the game, the Spaniard said: "I don't know [if Man City have the potential to win the Champions League]. Man City are desperate to make Champions League success a reality (Photo: Getty) 
"I know how complicated the competition is in terms of set pieces and losing concentration. I think honestly I am not able to talk about if we are able to win the Champions League. 
"But be sure, we are going to try, be sure of that." Man City are NOT overawed by the Champions League 
Guardiola acknowledged that his side have little history in the Champions League, but refused to suggest that this would hold them back in anyway. 
Speaking to the press, the Spaniard pointed out that his side deserve to be in the competition, and his players are professionals. 
"We don't have the long history of the other clubs, so if we go through to the quarter-finals it will be the second time in the club's whole history," said Guaridola. Man City are not intimidated by the competition (Photo: Laurence Griffiths) 
"It's a football game that we have to try and win, we have to focus on what we have to do, and all the clubs in Europe want to win the Champions League. 
"But the Champions League is not easy and to be here, for us, is a big success. Talking about a complex, all the players are so professional, they show it against big teams. 
"We are here because we deserve to be." Guardiola has no new injury concerns 
Aside from Gabriel Jesus and Ilkay Gundogan, the Spaniard has a fresh bill of health in which to select his first XI from. 
Monaco on the other hand are without some key players, which could make all the difference as they look to turn this tie around. Gabriel Jesus is still out with an injury (Photo: Michael Steele / Getty) 
Polish centre-back Kamil Glik is a huge player for the French giants, but will miss the game through suspension.
